front.question: A young male jumped from a tree and landed feet first. Which aspect of his body has sustained the initial injury?
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: Which of the following anatomic terms is synonymous with the word “dorsal”?
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: After applying a tourniquet, the injury from a patient’s leg stops bleeding. This is called:
front.source: See Master Tables

front.question: A patient has fractured both femurs. Anatomically, these injuries would be described as being:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: In relation to the chest, the back is:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: The ___________ of the heart is the inferior portion of the ventricles.
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

choices: a rapid heart rate that originates from above the ventricles.
a rapid heart rate that originates from within the ventricles.
a slow heart rate that originates from above the ventricles.
a slow heart rate that originates from within the ventricles.
front.question: The term “supraventricular tachycardia” means:
front.source: See Master Tables

cards.back: a rapid heart rate that originates from above the ventricles.

front.question: A diabetic patient has polydipsia. This means that she:
front.source: See Master Tables

front.question: An intoxicated 40-year-old male is found lying face down. How would you document his body’s position?
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: A fracture of the humerus just above the elbow would be described as a:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: Movement or motion away from the body’s midline is called:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: The topographic term used to describe the parts of the body that are nearer to the feet is:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: In relation to the wrist, the elbow is:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: Enlargement of the liver is called:
front.source: See Master Tables

front.question: The topographic term used to describe the location of body parts that are closer toward the midline of the body is:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: A patient in a semi-reclined position with the head elevated to facilitate breathing is in the ___________ position.
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

front.question: A 5-year-old boy has fallen and has a severe deformity of the forearm near the wrist. He has possibly sustained a fracture of the ____________ forearm.
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

choices: only one side of his chest rises when he inhales.
his chest and his abdomen are moving in opposite directions.
both of his lungs are expanding when he inhales.
both sides of his chest are moving minimally.
front.question: A patient with a pneumothorax has unilateral chest expansion. This means that:
front.source: See Common Direction, Movement, and Position Terms

cards.back: only one side of his chest rises when he inhales.

choices: her unborn baby is very large.
front.question: A pregnant patient is diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum. This means that:
front.source: See Breaking Terms Apart

choices: the removal of fluid from around the heart.
a surgical opening made in the heart.
narrowing of the arteries supplying the heart.
surgical repair of the sac around the heart.
front.question: The term “pericardiocentesis” means:
front.source: See Master Tables

cards.back: the removal of fluid from around the heart.
